The Congress acknowledges the United States' leading role in oil production and the potential benefits of authorizing crude oil exports, such as boosting domestic energy production, creating jobs, strengthening national defense, and increasing State and Federal revenues. An energy-secure U.S. as a net exporter could positively impact global security, particularly in Europe and the Middle East, providing more secure supply options for allies like Europe and Israel. The Maritime Security Fleet program ensures US-flag ships and crews are available to support the military, strengthening alliances and reducing energy as a political weapon. It provides skilled American mariners for both government-owned and commercial fleets in peace and war. The United States has reduced oil consumption over the past decade, and investing in clean energy technology and energy efficiency will lower energy prices, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and enhance national security. SEC. 2. REPEAL.

Section 103 of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act (42 U.S.C. 6212) and the item in the table of contents related to it are repealed.

SEC. 3. NATIONAL POLICY ON OIL EXPORT RESTRICTION.

To promote efficient exploration, production, storage, supply, marketing, pricing, and regulation of energy resources, no Federal Government official shall impose any restriction on crude oil export.

SEC. 4. STUDY AND RECOMMENDATIONS. The Secretary of Energy is required to conduct a study and provide recommendations on the Strategic Petroleum Reserve's appropriate size, composition, and purpose within 120 days of the enactment of this Act. Additionally, a study on the net greenhouse gas emissions resulting from the repeal of the crude oil export ban must be conducted and reported to the relevant committees within the same timeframe. The Secretary of Energy will conduct a study and provide recommendations on the Strategic Petroleum Reserve's size, composition, and purpose. The Department of Commerce, in consultation with the Department of Energy, will study the economic impact of lifting the crude oil export ban on the US economy. The Bureau of Industry and Security will conduct a study on the economic impact of exporting crude oil, including effects on the economy, consumers, domestic manufacturing, and the refining sector. A report will be submitted to Congress within one year of the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. SAVINGS CLAUSE. The President's authority under various laws to impose sanctions on foreign persons or governments, including state sponsors of terrorism, is not limited by this Act. SEC. 6. NATIONAL DEFENSE SEALIFT ENHANCEMENT. Payments under section 53106(a)(1) of title 46, United States Code are amended for fiscal years 2017 to 2021. Authorization of appropriations under section 53111 is also adjusted for the same fiscal years. For fiscal years 2017 to 2021, payments under section 53106(a)(1) of title 46, United States Code are amended. Authorization of appropriations under section 53111 is adjusted accordingly. The funding amounts for these years are specified as follows: $299,997,000 for 2017, $300,000,000 for each of 2018, 2019, and 2020, and $314,007,780 for 2021. The Department of Energy will partner with minority serving institutions like Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities in the energy sector. They will also promote public-private partnerships. A report will be submitted to Congress after 10 years to review the impact of lifting the oil export ban on US energy and national security. The Secretary of Energy and the Secretary of Commerce will report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment on how lifting the crude oil export ban will benefit veterans and women in the US, as well as enhance energy and national security. The Act prohibits the export of crude oil, refined petroleum products, and petrochemical products to the Islamic Republic of Iran. The House of Representatives passed the Act on October 9, 2015.
